response.answer_text: Many of my students find listening the most difficult English skill to master. But this is only until they try the following tips.  1. Have regular conversations with native speakers. Hearing natural English speech regularly is definitely the best way to improve your English listening. It’s only through constant practice that you will get to the place you want. Speaking with native speakers will help you on many different levels. a) You will hear natural English – the way it is used in real life. b) You will learn to listen to context – to chunks of words, instead of individual words. c) It will keep your mind open to the various ways of using and hearing English, instead of solely the textbook English, which most students are used to. If you think that speaking regularly with native English speakers isn’t so simple, I am telling you that it really is. Just go to English Ninjas – we have many experienced native English-speaking tutors who are ready to help you improve. Just sign up and start practicing your English as often as you want, whenever you want. Tell us that you are a Quora user, and you will get a discount! Click here to learn more about English Ninjas. 2. Make listening a part of your life. I know. When you are somewhat new to English and you listen to native speech on TV or the radio, everything sounds like a blur or a run-on sentence, and you think to yourself, “How am I ever going to make heads or tails out of this?” But you will. You just have to stick to it, and, ideally, practice every day. I know that you are probably too busy to allocate time for English listening every single day, but try not to make it into a task. Weave it into your life in a seamless way. Listen to podcasts on topics you are most interested in as you exercise, put on an audiobook on your way to work or school, tune on to your favorite radio station as you are making breakfast, listen to English songs to relax, etc. Once you make this a daily habit, those seemingly run-on sentences will soon start making sense. 3. Listen to the same podcast several times You know how I recommended listening to podcasts in the previous point? I’ll give you another tip. Try to listen to the same podcast episode every day of the week. During your first couple of days, go back to words that you don’t understand and look them up in the dictionary. By the end of the week, you should be able to discern those words in the podcast and pick up the context in which they are used. This technique will develop your active listening, that is, listening during which you pay close attention to what is being said, how it is being said and make an effort to extract meaning from it.

I'm a native English speaker who has learnt French to a high level. How I came to more or less master French can be applied to any language though. When I first arrived in Switzerland and had to interact with French-speaking people, I could barely understand two words in what seemed like a long line of random sounds issuing from their mouths. I did, however, have a good base level in French vocabulary. This is important for what followed. I started talking to French-speaking people. I had to take three times as long as I worked out what I wanted to say then translate it into French but eventually I got the words out. What I found was that people then answered me back using similar words that I could then pick out. The more I did this, the more I could understand. I also got faster at translating in my head until one day, I no longer needed to translate. I'm currently at a C1 level for written and oral expression and a C2 level for written and oral comprehension. This means that even with accents that I'm unfamiliar with I can understand if given a bit of time to adapt and familiarize myself with it. Now, you may not be in a situation where you can practice daily with a native speaker of English. If you can practice with someone, even if it's your teacher at school for the few hours a week you have class, don't miss the opportunity. The more conversation you have, the more you'll understand. However, this is not enough or you may not be in school. In that case, as a poor but better than nothing substitute, try to have as many internal dialogs as you can. Ask yourself how your day went and then answer yourself. Seek out videos and tv shows that may have this type of dialog, hit pause and see if you can answer then listen for the character’s response. Did it match what you said? What did / didn't you understand? Listen again, try to respond again. If you are consistent, you should see signs of improvement. Also try reading out loud to get practice for the sound of words. Audio books that you can follow along with the actual book could also be a good way to get your ear used to the sound of words when spoken but try to choose a book with lots of dialog. Just remember that just like with any skill, practice, practice, practice. There simply is no substitute for putting in the effort.

Firstly, congratulations that you have avoided the mistake that a large proportion of language learners make, and that's to under-appreciate the importance of listening. OK, moving on, my background to this is that (other than my native English) I've learned 2 languages to fluency, and have varying levels of 4 more. I owe much of my language abilities to a focus on listening, and am such a believer in its power that I even started a podcast for English learners. So then, how to improve your listening abilities? Well, firstly we need to dissect the different 'skills' that you will need to develop to improve your listening abilities, and we can look at the ways in which you can improve each one. 1. Vocabulary Firstly, vocabulary. Quite simply, if you hear a new word you don’t understand there are 2 possibilities: a) you can understand, or make a best guess at it, through context. This means that you understand the rest of the sentence, and contextually you can understand what a particular word means. b) you can’t understand the word through context and need to look it up. This is fine, and completely to be expected. The only way you learn is by encountering things you don’t know. In both cases, you should write down the new word. Practice repeating it in the same way that it was spoken by the native speaker (yes, speaking it will help you remember it next time you hear it), and keep it in your notebook. If you continue to do this for every new word you hear, you will find yourself having to write down fewer and fewer words, as your understanding will continually improve. 2. Grammar Similarly to vocabulary, if there is a particular grammatical form used, look it up. Write it down. Practice using it. The more you repeat this, the more familiar you will find yourself with different grammatical structures. 3. Sentence structure In any language, people do not speak in the same way in which they right. English is no exception. Not of course that he is any example of how to speak coherently, but have you ever read a transcript from Donald Trump speaking? He is an extreme example, however native speakers do not speak in the same way as they write. By familiarising yourself with the differences in speech vs. writing, you will find it easier to understand the speech of native speakers. 4. Connected speech Unlike several other languages (especially many East Asian languages), English speakers will use ‘connected speech’. In plain English, this means that when words are spoken, their pronunciation will change slightly depending on what words come before or after. You can see more examples here, but I’ve put some below fish and chips (fish´n chips)a chair and a table (a chair ´n a table)CanShe can speak Spanish better than I can (The first "can" is the weak form, the second the full form.)OfA pint of beerThat´s the last of the wine!HaveHave you finished? (weak)Yes, I have. (full)ShouldWell, you should have told me. (Both "should" and "have" are weak here)When listening with a transcript, if there is a word that changes its pronunciation due to connected speech, note that down so you will remember it for next time. 5. Auditory discrimination In plain English, this is the ability to differentiate between two sounds. For non-native speakers, it’s important to be able to differentiate between phonemes, or very similar sounding sounds. For example ‘sister’ and ‘sitter’, or ‘cat’ and ‘cot’. Depending on your native language, some sounds will be harder to differentiate than others. Although you can improve these skills through contextual understanding, you should listen to audio with a transcript available, so that you can always double check the exact word if you are not sure. 6. Accent & regional differences I’ve left this for last, for 2 reasons: a) If you are living in an English-speaking country or area, then you should focus on listening to conversations in the accent of the region you are in. Don’t worry too much about understanding accents that you won’t encounter. b) All of the above points have variations based on accent and regions. In any case, being able to recognise and understand the accents of different places can be difficult even for native speakers, and for many non-native speakers, it just isn’t that necessary. If you are learning English for the purposes of living in Sydney, you shouldn’t be that concerned about not being able to understand a Geordie (from Newcastle, UK) accent, as you will very rarely encounter this accent.  So, what can you actually do to improve your listening skills? 1. Active listening -> don’t be a ‘passive’ listener By passive, I mean that you just let the words flow over you. Instead, as an active listener, you need to listen to every single word, every single turn of phrase that's used. Use the above points to guide you. If you're listening to a podcast, or some kind of audio that allows pausing / rewinding, use this functionality to its full potential. If you didn't understand a particular word or sentence, go back and listen again. Use audio that comes with transcripts and key vocabulary, and use that as a ‘crutch’ if you get stuck. Don’t default to just reading the transcript because it’s easier. 2. Transcribe -> be an ‘ultra’ active listener Although others have touched on the idea of transcribing, there are 2 major ways in which you can transcribe to help your listening. a) Transcribe the exact words that were said This will help you to make sure that you have understood every word - or at least understood how to write every word - and will help develop your sentence structure, auditory discrimination, and connected speech comprehension. b) Listen to the audio, then try to summarise what you have heard On one level this is easier, because you don’t have to transcript every single word. But on another level it’s harder, as you need to come up with your own words to describe what you have heard. It’s more similar to ‘real life’, as in real life it’s possible to skip over parts, and comprehension of the subject is more important than comprehension of a single word. Experiment with both, and you will see your listening skills develop very quickly. If you have the chance (e.g. a native speaker friend, or teacher), then show them what you have summarised and get them to check it for accuracy. 3. Don’t go for the easy option Yes, this might not be what you want to hear, but normally the activities which are the most taxing and difficult will be the ways in which you learn the most effectively. For listening comprehension, many may say ‘watch netflix’, ‘just watch videos on YouTube’. Of course, this is better than nothing, but will not be the fastest way to improve. I can’t stress this enough. Video is contextual, meaning that you have the film to help you understand, and you don’t need to focus on the actual language. Your mind is busy processing everything else, and you aren’t focussing 100% on the language. Similarly, things like listening to songs in English may seem like fun, and it’s better than nothing. But your mind isn’t 100% focussed on listening, PLUS the language and structures used in songs are often peculiar and don’t reflect how English is actually spoken (see Will listening to English songs improve my spoken English? for a more in-depth explanation of this) 4. Carve out a set period of time and stick to it. It’s the easiest thing in the world to ‘decide to learn’ a language. Actually creating a schedule and sticking to it is so much harder. Especially with listening, which is a skill that some people naively think can be developed just by ‘being present and opening their ears’ (see #3), you need to be religious about sticking to a schedule of active learning. This doesn’t mean that you need to spend 5 hrs per day doing listening exercises, it means that you need to pick an amount of time, and make sure that you aren’t falling into the trap of doing easy things that feel fun. As an example, most students will learn significantly faster by actively listening to and doing transcription exercises with a podcast for 60 mins (so a total of 1hr) than they would by watching 2 films on Netflix in English then spending an hour listening to English songs (total of 5 hrs). I know I’d much rather do 1hr of intense ‘difficult’ work than 5 hours or ‘fun and easy’ work, but it just depends on you.  Learning a language isn’t easy, it doesn’t happen passively, and (despite what the internet may say / what you may like to hear) there aren’t ‘hacks’ that mean you don’t have to work at it. Best of luck in your learning journey!

How do I practice English listening effectively? You should understand that listening is a skill and you should train it – NOT learn it. Learning is memorizing facts about the language; training is experiencing something many times until the brain develops a skill. Driving a car, figure skating, playing a musical instrument, martial arts or speaking a foreign language or developing listening skill – all of these skills are trained, i.e. performed many times with minimal conscious effort. During training of these skills, the brain finds and records the patterns that it can perform after training without conscious effort and with minimal attention, i.e. effortlessly. There is another reason why adults have difficulties in developing speaking or listening skills: the native language comes to dominate the linguistic map space and all incoming information must be translated into the mother tongue to become understandable. This phenomenon is known as “The Tyranny of the Mother Tongue.” Most adults, when learning a foreign language, subconsciously revert to cross-translation to and from their mother tongue. Cross-translation is the main barrier most teachers and educators ignore. When you cross-translate, you think in your native language while trying to speak in a foreign language or listening to the recording in English or conversation. It is very stressful and is the main reason why you need to develop listening skills. I have developed and patented the method that stops cross-translation automatically. You need to perform simultaneous training of reading, listening and speaking skills. When learner performs simultaneous repetition, his natural habit of thinking in the native language is turned off automatically. This tool allows adult learners to automatically form direct wiring between English words and images or symbols, they describe. Learners start thinking in English from the first lesson. The way to become a better listener? Practice active listening. This is where you make a conscious effort to hear not only the words that another person is saying but, more importantly, try to understand the complete message being sent. In order to do this, you must pay attention to the other person very carefully. You cannot allow yourself to become distracted by whatever else may be going on around you, or by forming counter-arguments that you'll make when the other person stops speaking. Nor can you allow yourself to get bored, and lose focus on what the other person is saying. All of these contribute to a lack of listening and understanding. Related post: Communications are Key to Building Customer Trust There are five key elements of active listening. They all help you ensure that you hear the other person and that the other person knows you are hearing what they say. Listen carefully Give the speaker your undivided attention, and acknowledge the message. Recognize that non-verbal communication also "speaks" loudly. Defer Judgment Interrupting is a waste of time. It frustrates the speaker and limits a full understanding of the message. Respond Appropriately Active listening is a model for respect and understanding. You are gaining information and perspective. You add nothing by attacking the speaker or otherwise putting him or her down. Show That You're Listening Use your own body language and gestures to convey your attention. Provide Feedback Our personal filters, assumptions, judgments, and beliefs can distort what we hear. As a listener, your role is to understand what is being said. This may require you to reflect what is being said and ask questions. It is really very simple. Demonstrate that you're listening. Paraphrase, re-state and react to what you hear. There are a few techniques that I’ve found very useful for my students. A very popular method is to watch DVDs in English with the English sub-titles on. If you don’t yet have the vocabulary to understand what people are saying, it’s pointless to guess. Sub-titles provide a lot of valuable information. You can use the pause button to stop the DVD if the audio is going too fast and replay - this also gives you the opportunity to polish your pronunciation by copying unfamiliar words. One of the biggest problems with DVDs, however, is the speed at which actors speak, making it very hard to follow. Movie scripts also tend to be full of idioms, many of which are hard for English learners to understand. Because of this, I use a lot of TED talks for listening comprehension in my classes. There are thousands of these available online on a huge variety of topics - all free! What’s great about TED talks is that every one of them has a transcript so you can follow what the speaker is saying. I usually copy and paste the transcript onto a Word document, print it out and have students read it along with the speaker. Of course, TED speakers also talk at a very fast pace, but there is less idiomatic speech and less action and drama than you will find in a movie, so overall these talks are much easier to follow and understand. Finally there are a couple of great listening resources available here in Australia but they do cost money. AMES Australia produces 2 CDs which are called ‘That’s Life’ and ‘That’s Work’. They have dozens of excellent listening activities on a very wide range of subjects. The CDs cost about $80 Australian each and I think they ship overseas.

Unlike in the reading and writing parts of the test, you are not in control of the timing of the listening test so it is vital that you use the time you are given before and after each section of the test to read the questions and check your answers. Make predictions about possible answers and type of word or words (noun, verb, adjective or numbers etc) the answer might contain before each listening section. After each section go back over your answers to check you have not made any simple mistakes. However, if you are very confident about your answers, you might want to use that checking the time to go to the next section to prepare for that instead. Highlight/circle/underline the keywords in the questions/diagrams etc. Make sure you follow the order of the questions in tables (top to bottom or left to right?) and diagrams (clockwise, anticlockwise or dotted around?) and understand what information is required and/or what the diagram/process is showing. Many candidates spend a lot of time practicing for the IELTS listening test by doing old tests from test books. This is obviously a good idea as it helps make the test more familiar. However, repeated practice of just one test type will not improve your general listening skills very much and you need to take time with other listening sources as well. Try using a graded reader: listen to it in small chunks and write what you hear, checking back for spelling and grammatical accuracy. Use the internet to listen to BBC news items making notes on what you hear. Listen again (with or without subtitles) to check your information. TED talks are another very good source of detailed practice for the IELTS listening test. For section one you need to be sure you know the English alphabet and how each letter is pronounced in spelling words such as people’s names and place names. Also, you will hear information given in numerical form. This information is simple but can be given quite rapidly so do some practice with phone numbers, prices, time and dates, percentages, fractions etc. Section two of the IELTS listening test contains general information given as a monologue. To practice in advance you need to listen to instructions, tour guides and the like. Sometimes this involves a map so practice with language of directions (north, south, next to, behind, opposite etc). Section three is an academic discussion, often between students and a tutor. This might involve language of decision making, giving reasons and opinions especially in the area of choosing courses, study topics and reviewing assignments.

It's been said that the most important skill to master in any language is listening. I think another common notion in language learning is that real mastery is only learned through experience gained in conversational speech. it's because a surprising variety of nuances will occur to you as you listen to spoken (rather than read written) language. Hence, it will also sharpen your ear to listen closely to English, because it has many idioms and rule exceptions. Once you learn most of the rules and exceptions, you’ll have the basis for learning about poetic and other special cases, and much more modern English like that used in rapping. This is why if you are comparatively new to English, I’d suggest that you do not plunge directly into a lot of Shakespeare and Joyce, even in the theater. Instead, I’d suggest watching films from the 1940s (in which most film dialouge was very carefully written and performed). In the 1950s there was a cloud of anti-communism that affected film scripts (e.g., some of Hollywood’s best writers were excluded), and in the mid-1960s and beyond, film dialogue may be too “modern” to be readily grasped on first hearing.

It can be very helpful to watch television and movies with subtitles on in English, not in your language. Read as you listen. Understand that you will not hear every single word. We reduce a lot of words in English, so you need to listen for content words (nouns, verbs, adjectives) and not worry quite as much about function words (prepositions, articles, conjunctions), at least at first. If you can generally get the main idea of what is being said from the content words, then it's a good idea to start focusing on the ways we reduce and link certain sounds. An easy example is that “want to” generally sounds like one word: “wanna”. But there are lots of other similar patterns to watch for. Don't focus on understanding every single word. Start with movies you have already seen in your language so that you don't get frustrated trying to understand. Also, go back, rewind 30 seconds when you want to hear something again. Look for patterns. I hope this helps!

Intense listening is like riding a bike: the more you do it, the easier it gets. For the time being, consciously follow word by word. We can all think faster than we speak, so it is tempting sometimes to fill in the end of the sentence you're hearing and start thinking about something else. Try behaving like a reporter: make notes on a conversation, and try to write it out word for word. You won't have much luck early on, but you could train yourself to drop the old habits and start positively listening. As well as the dictation method, try to summarise what you've just heard in a couple of sentences. For relaxation, get audio books from your library and listen for pleasure. Anything more complex than Young Adult stuff will tone up your listening muscles and change your mind-wandering habits.

You can colour code them by using different colours for different films and shows or episodes. Then, gradually move on to English subtitles and continue the process of note-taking.
